messageBody:
On Thu, May 21, 2009 at 12:38 PM, Pigneri, Rocco <rpigneri@...> wrote:
>> >
> assertReturned(stringContaining("foo")).from(someObject).someMethod();
>>
>> Aber ja!
>
>
>
> I like this notation as well, but I'm concerned that it leads us right
> back to where we were before: having to use Hamcrest matchers and having
> to remember to import statically a large collection of classes in order
> to use the library.
>
>
> I'm wondering if maybe we are trying to solve the wrong problem, and if
> maybe a reorg of Hamcrest could be a better solution tothis problem.  As
> a comparison, .NET's NUnit has managed to implement something similar to
> Hamcrest using only a few top level classes (Is, Has, Text, Throws,
> List, and After-as a scan of the documentation tells me).  The user is
> then able to write a lot of very succinct tests with few imports:
>
>
>
> Assert.That(list, Has.All.GreaterThan(5));
>
> Assert.That(List.Map(strings).Property("Length"),
> Is.EqualTo(lengthsList));
>
>
>
> This notation is achieved via .NET properties.  A property is basically
> a function that is executed using the same syntax as a public member
> variable, thus allowing for simple gating of otherwise public members in
> order to ensure that all internal invariants are met.  I am pretty sure
> that properties as they exist in .NET are not available in Java at all;
> however, this comparison does raise the question of whether or not the
> issues that we are having with Hamcrest could be solved via either
> better organization of the existing matchers or through better leverage
> of Java's features.  Perhaps someone with more Java experience than I
> could speak to this?

Well, this might solve some problems that are being had with Hamcrest,
but it doesn't truly address either of the first two concerns raised:

1) The verbosity of assertThat(b, is(true)).
2) The difficulty of creating new matchers that wrap existing methods.

Your proposal would be easily satisfied with a third-party library,
using static inner classes. Please give it a try, and publicize it if
you find it solves your problems.

David Saff
